title: If superpowers were real: Super speed - Joy Lin

multiple-choice.question: Why can't humans travel at speeds of 25,000 miles per hour without suffering damage?

options.label: A
options.text: Because air is not empty, and friction generates heat that would burn our faces off.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brains are too fragile to handle the sudden movement.

options.label: C
options.text: Because we would run out of oxygen and nitrogen in the air.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we would crash into the nearest wall at super speed.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why humans can't withstand the sudden movement of acceleration at super speed?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our internal organs would crash into the front of our bodies.

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brains would crash into the side of our skulls.

options.label: C
options.text: Because our bodies would turn into mush.

options.label: D
options.text: Because we would lose consciousness.

multiple-choice.question: According to Newton's First Law of Motion, what is the resistance to a change in its state of motion called?

options.label: A
options.text: Inertia

options.label: B
options.text: Acceleration

options.label: C
options.text: Velocity

options.label: D
options.text: Friction

multiple-choice.question: Why is it mathematically the same to run someone over with a space shuttle at maximum speed as to accelerate them to 25,000 miles per hour and then suddenly stop?

options.label: A
options.text: Because the speed causes the damage.

options.label: B
options.text: Because the acceleration or sudden stop causes the damage.

options.label: C
options.text: Because the friction generates heat that would burn their faces off.

options.label: D
options.text: Because their brain would crash into the side of their skull.

multiple-choice.question: What would happen to a person's body if they were to move at super speed and then suddenly stop?

options.label: A
options.text: They would turn into a missile that destroys everything in their path.

options.label: B
options.text: They would suffer millions of tiny cuts from the sand and dirt in the air.

options.label: C
options.text: They would burn up from the heat generated by friction.

options.label: D
options.text: They would experience a rapid increase in velocity that would crash their brain into the side of their skull.

title: Equality, sports, and Title IX - Erin Buzuvis and Kristine Newhall

multiple-choice.question: What was the main goal of the Title IX law passed in 1972?

options.label: A
options.text: To increase the number of boys playing sports

options.label: B
options.text: To protect girls and women from discrimination in schools, colleges, and universities

options.label: C
options.text: To promote equality in education, but not in sports

options.label: D
options.text: To reduce the number of girls participating in sports

multiple-choice.question: What are the three tests that schools can follow to demonstrate fairness in opportunities for girls under Title IX?

options.label: A
options.text: Proportionality, equality, and satisfaction

options.label: B
options.text: Progress, proportionality, and satisfied interests

options.label: C
options.text: Participation, treatment, and proportionality

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What does the term "proportionality" mean in the context of Title IX?

options.label: A
options.text: The number of girls playing sports should be equal to the number of boys

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is another important part of Title IX, aside from ensuring equal opportunities for girls and boys?

options.text: Ensuring that girls have more time to practice than boys

options.label: B
options.text: Ensuring that girls have equal access to locker rooms, practice spaces, and competitive facilities

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: The number of books you read each week.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are not exposed to new experiences.

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What lesson can we learn from time perception about how to live our lives?

options.label: B
options.text: That we should not engage with the world and have new experiences.

options.label: C
options.text: That we should get up and engage with the world and have new experiences.

options.label: D
options.text: That we should only travel to familiar places.

multiple-choice.question: What is pseudocode, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A programming language used to write algorithms.

options.label: B
options.text: A set of instructions for solving a problem, written in English-like syntax.

options.label: C
options.text: A set of instructions for solving a problem, written in a programming language.

options.label: D
options.text: A set of instructions for solving a problem, written in a natural language.

multiple-choice.question: What is a corner case, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A case where the algorithm is executed with a large number of people in the room.

options.label: B
options.text: A case where the algorithm is executed with a small number of people in the room.

options.label: C
options.text: A case where the algorithm is executed with zero people in the room.

options.label: D
options.text: A case where the algorithm is executed with a negative number of people in the room.

multiple-choice.question: What is a branch in an algorithm, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: A sequence of steps that will repeat some number of times.

options.label: B
options.text: A condition that only executes if a certain condition is met.

options.label: C
options.text: A variable that is used to store a value.

options.label: D
options.text: A function that is used to perform a calculation.

title: The Watergate scandal: United States vs. Nixon

multiple-choice.question: What was the initial reason for the Watergate scandal?

options.label: A
options.text: A security guard noticed that a few doors were taped so that they were left unlocked.

options.label: B
options.text: A group of people were trying to break into the White House.

options.label: C
options.text: A security guard at the Watergate complex noticed that a few doors were taped so that they were left unlocked.

options.label: D
options.text: A group of people were trying to steal sensitive information from the CIA.

multiple-choice.question: Who were the five men arrested on account of attempted burglary and attempted interception of telephone and other communications?

options.label: A
options.text: Virgilio Gonzales, Bernard Barker, James W. McCord Jr., Eugene O. Martinez, and Frank Sturgis

options.label: B
options.text: E. Howard Hunt, G. Gordon Liddy, Virgilio Gonzales, Bernard Barker, and James W. McCord Jr.

options.label: C
options.text: Virgilio Gonzales, Bernard Barker, James W. McCord Jr., Eugene O. Martinez, and G. Gordon Liddy

options.label: D
options.text: E. Howard Hunt, G. Gordon Liddy, James W. McCord Jr., Eugene O. Martinez, and Frank Sturgis

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the "smoking gun tape"?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a conversation between Nixon and Halderman discussing the cover-up plan.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a conversation between Nixon and Halderman discussing the break-in.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a conversation between Nixon and Halderman discussing the campaign.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a conversation between Nixon and Halderman discussing the investigation.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Nixon decide to resign?

options.label: A
options.text: He was told that enough votes existed to remove him from office.

options.label: B
options.text: He was told that he would be impeached.

options.label: C
options.text: He was told that he would be arrested.

options.label: D
options.text: He realized that he no longer had the support of the Congress.

multiple-choice.question: What was the impact of the Watergate scandal on American society?

options.label: A
options.text: It led to a decrease in trust in the government.

options.label: B
options.text: It led to an increase in trust in the government.

options.label: C
options.text: It had no impact on American society.

options.label: D
options.text: It led to a decrease in corruption in the government.

options.text: Particle field

options.label: C

title: Leaders and followers: what tango teaches

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the terms "leader" and "follower" in Tango, according to Sha and Isaac?

options.label: A
options.text: They are gender-specific roles.

options.label: B
options.text: They are interchangeable terms.

options.label: C
options.text: They are gender-neutral terms.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not used in Tango.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between a "weak follower" and a "strong follower" in Tango, as demonstrated by Sha and Isaac?

options.label: A
options.text: A weak follower is one who takes responsibility for their own movements, while a strong follower is one who is passive.

options.label: B
options.text: A weak follower is one who is passive, while a strong follower is one who takes responsibility for their own movements.

options.label: C
options.text: A weak follower is one who is creative, while a strong follower is one who is not.

options.label: D
options.text: A weak follower is one who is strong, while a strong follower is one who is weak.

multiple-choice.question: What is "self-serving following" in Tango, as demonstrated by Sha and Isaac?

options.label: A
options.text: It is when the follower takes responsibility for their own movements and creates their own steps.

options.label: B
options.text: It is when the follower is more interested in their own steps than in co-creating the dance with their partner.

options.label: C
options.text: It is when the leader is more interested in their own steps than in co-creating the dance with their partner.

options.label: D
options.text: It is when the follower is passive and does not take responsibility for their own movements.

multiple-choice.question: What is "fighting against the leader" in Tango, as demonstrated by Sha and Isaac?

options.label: A
options.text: It is when the follower takes responsibility for their own movements and creates their own steps.

options.label: B
options.text: It is when the follower does not respect the vision of the leader and changes the course of the dance.

options.label: C
options.text: It is when the leader is more interested in their own steps than in co-creating the dance with their partner.

options.label: D
options.text: It is when the follower is passive and does not take responsibility for their own movements.

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of a strong follower in Tango, as demonstrated by Sha and Isaac?

options.label: A
options.text: To create their own steps and movements.

options.label: B
options.text: To stabilize the leader and keep the dance moving along in a fluid way.

options.label: C
options.text: To be passive and not take responsibility for their own movements.

options.label: D
options.text: To change the course of the dance and go against the leader's vision.

options.text: They can help with household chores.

multiple-choice.question: According to Kathryn Minshew, what is the first step to networking?

options.label: A
options.text: Show up and often.

options.label: B
options.text: Always say yes to invitations.

options.label: C
options.text: When you want something, broadcast it to everyone you meet.

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: So you can ask for help as soon as you meet them.

multiple-choice.question: What is the third step to networking according to Kathryn Minshew?

options.label: A
options.text: Always say yes to invitations.

options.label: B
options.text: When you want something, broadcast it to everyone you meet.

options.label: C
options.text: Show up and often.

options.label: D
options.text: Be at the forefront of other's minds when opportunities arise.
